member.name: T:CityIndex.JsonClient.CacheItemState
member.summary: Describes the state of a

member.name: F:CityIndex.JsonClient.CacheItemState.New
member.summary: The item was created and inserted by the cache and is ready to be populated

member.name: F:CityIndex.JsonClient.CacheItemState.Pending
member.summary: The item's request has been issued and is waiting for completion. While in this state, additional callbacks may be added for identical requests enabling a single request to service multiple calls.

member.name: F:CityIndex.JsonClient.CacheItemState.Processing
member.summary: The item's request has completed, or errored out, and the item's callbacks are currently being executed. The item and the cache should be locked and blocking while an item is in this state.

member.name: F:CityIndex.JsonClient.CacheItemState.Complete
member.summary:
The item's request has completed, or errored out, and the item contains the request's response text, if any, and any exception thrown.
Expiration date is computed at this transition.

member.name: T:CityIndex.JsonClient.ThrottledRequestQueue
member.summary:
A self throttling asynchronous request queue.
TODO: allow for pausing would like to allow for clearing the queue but dependencies on the cache make this a non starter. the only viable ways to that means is to merge throttle and cache. this will have to be a builder type action in the calling class that can corelate the queue items and the cache items and resolve the cache items that are cleared. this will probably mean the introduction of a 'cancelled' CacheItemState

member.name: T:CityIndex.JsonClient.IThrottledRequestQueue
member.summary: Describes a self throttling asynchronous request queue.

member.name: M:CityIndex.JsonClient.IThrottledRequestQueue.Enqueue(System.String,System.Net.WebRequest,System.Action{System.IAsyncResult,CityIndex.JsonClient.RequestHolder})
member.summary: Adds a request to the end of the queue.

member.name: P:CityIndex.JsonClient.IThrottledRequestQueue.Scope
member.summary: The name/key of this throttle

member.name: P:CityIndex.JsonClient.IThrottledRequestQueue.DispatchedCount
member.summary: The number of requests that have been dispatched

member.name: P:CityIndex.JsonClient.IThrottledRequestQueue.MaxPendingRequests
member.summary:
The maximum number of allowed pending request.
The throttle window will keep us in compliance with the letter of the law, but testing has shown that a large number of outstanding requests result in a cascade of (500) errors that does not stop.
So we will defer processing while there are > MaxPendingRequests regardless of throttle window.

member.name: P:CityIndex.JsonClient.IThrottledRequestQueue.PendingRequests
member.summary: The number of pending (issued) requests

member.name: P:CityIndex.JsonClient.IThrottledRequestQueue.ThrottleWindowCount
member.summary: The quantitive portion (xxx) of the of 30 requests per 5 seconds

member.name: P:CityIndex.JsonClient.IThrottledRequestQueue.ThrottleWindowTime
member.summary: The temporal portion (yyy) of the of 30 requests per 5 seconds

member.name: M:CityIndex.JsonClient.ThrottledRequestQueue.#ctor
member.summary: Insantiates a with default parameters. throttleWindowTime = 5 seconds throttleWindowCount = 30 maxPendingRequests = 10

member.summary: Insantiates a with supplied parameters.
member.param: The window in which to restrice issued requests to
The maximum number of requests to issue in the amount of time described by
The maximum allowed number of active requests.

member.name: T:CityIndex.JsonClient.Client
member.summary: Provides a simple, yet fully functional, strongly typed json request dispatch replete with caching and throttling capabilities. Typically this class is used as a base for specialized derivations.

member.name: T:CityIndex.JsonClient.IJsonClient
member.summary: Describes a general purpose HTTP JSON API client

member.name: M:CityIndex.JsonClient.IJsonClient.Request``1(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Object},System.TimeSpan,System.String)
member.summary: Very simple synchronous wrapper of the begin/end methods. I have chosen not to simply use the synchronous .GetResponse() method of WebRequest to prevent evolution of code that will not port to silverlight. While it is against everything righteous and holy in the silverlight crowd to implement syncronous patterns, no matter how cleverly, there is just too much that can be done with a sync fetch, i.e. multi page, eager fetches, etc, to ignore it. We simply forbid usage on the UI thread with an exception. Simple.

member.name: M:CityIndex.JsonClient.IJsonClient.BeginRequest``1(CityIndex.JsonClient.ApiAsyncCallback{``0},System.Object,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Object},System.TimeSpan,System.String)
member.summary: Standard async Begin implementation.

member.name: M:CityIndex.JsonClient.IJsonClient.EndRequest``1(CityIndex.JsonClient.ApiAsyncResult{``0})
member.summary: Standard async end implementation. Calling code passes in the ApiAsyncResult that is returned to the callback and the response data is returned. If an exception occurred during execution of the request, it will now be rethrown.
member.exception: the exception, if any, that occurred during execution of the request

member.name: M:CityIndex.JsonClient.Client.BeforeIssueRequest(System.Net.WebRequest,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Object},System.TimeSpan,System.String)
member.summary:
Provides an interaction point after the request has been created but just before it is queued up for execution. Derived classes may take this opportunity to modify the , or the . The remaining parameters are for reference only and modification will have no effect on the execution of the request.
TODO: perhaps a container object for the read-only reference values to avoid any confusion? it could be argued that you can read the url of the request but having the components used to create the url could make life a lot easier. ?

member.name: M:CityIndex.JsonClient.Client.BeforeBuildUrl(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Object},System.TimeSpan,System.String)
member.summary: Provides a interaction point just before the url for the request is built. Derived classes may take this opportunity to examine and modify the components used to build the url for the request.

member.name: M:CityIndex.JsonClient.Client.Request``1(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.String,System.Object},System.TimeSpan,System.String)
member.summary: Very simple synchronous wrapper of the begin/end methods. I have chosen not to simply use the synchronous .GetResponse() method of WebRequest to prevent evolution of code that will not port to silverlight. While it is against everything righteous and holy in the silverlight crowd to implement syncronous patterns, no matter how cleverly, there is just too much that can be done with a sync fetch, i.e. multi page, eager fetches, etc, to ignore it. We simply forbid usage on the UI thread with an exception. Simple.

member.name: M:CityIndex.JsonClient.Client.Request``1(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Very simple synchronous wrapper of the begin/end methods.

member.name: T:CityIndex.JsonClient.CacheItem`1
member.summary: Provides a generic composition element for request state. Contains a callback queue to service identical concurrent requests. i.e. if, while a request is in process, an identical request is made, the caller may simply add the callback to this item and let the single request service both.
